A Blog Post with Every HTML Element?Â Almost. â€” Taking 18 months to come together, this post makes a brave attempt to squeeze every HTML element (including some former elements like <marquee> and <blink>) into a single place. Itâ€™s a fantastically retro-feeling reunion that starts off feeling a little dull but rapidly picks up theÂ pace, even if poor <applet> doesn't makeÂ theÂ cut..

Patrick Weaver

Frontend Masters sponsor

WordPress 6.3 â€œLionelâ€ Released â€” Hailed as a â€œmomentous releaseâ€, the universally popular CMS includes a new Site Editor experience, the ability to create and sync block â€˜patternsâ€™, new design tools, keyboard shortcut changes, style revision tracking, along with performance and accessibilityÂ improvements.

MatÃ­as Ventura (WordPress)

An Update on Chrome Security Updates: Shipping Security Fixes to You Faster â€” In an effort to reduce the â€œpatch gapâ€ and get security fixes out faster, Chrome is now shipping weekly Stable channelÂ updates. This doesn't affect the cadence of milestone updates, though, so Chrome 200 is still some wayÂ off.Â ğŸ¤­

Amy Ressler (Google)

  • You may start to see OpenAI's 'GPTBot' in your logs, as the company recently launched its own web crawler â€” which in turn sparked blocking efforts by website owners and creators.

  • FranÃ§ois Beaufort shares what's new in WebGPU in Chrome, including WebCodecs integration, video playback improvements, and more.

  • What's the biggest, valid z-index value you can specify in CSS? It may be â–¶ï¸ larger than you think.

  • The way in which downloads appear in Chrome has changed.

You can sign up for theÂ waitlist.

Google

Callstack sponsor

If youâ€™ve never experimented with React Three Fiber or creating visual effects before, this is a good introduction walking through the key parts of theirÂ approach.

Francesco Sansalvadore (Supabase)

What Does It Mean for Web Browsers to Have a 'Baseline' â€” Back in May we shared news on Baseline, a new project that aims to clarify what developers can rely on across browsers and the web platform in general. Mary recaps why it matters, how it will hopefully work, and even touches upon the browser politics of the newÂ project.

Mary Branscombe (The New Stack)

Smoothing Out the Scrolling Experience in Chrome on Android â€” A look at how the scrolling experience on Chrome for Android has been improved, reducing slow scrolling jank by 2x. The post shares how the Chromium team discovered and evaluated the problem, and how that helped them â€œdesign a better browser experience goingÂ forwardâ€.

Stephen Nusko (Google)

Optimizing Speed on eBay â€” â€œFor every 100 milliseconds improvement in search page loading time, eBay saw a 0.5% increase in â€˜Add to Cartâ€™ count.â€ â€”Â This perfectly highlights how important performance can be at such huge scale. Addy runs through just how the performance of eBayâ€™s sites and apps were optimized for a faster overall userÂ experience.

Addy Osmani

Addy didn't just stop with looking at eBay, he also took a look at YouTube's efforts to increase their Core Web Vitals pass rates.

Designing Accessible Text Over Images: Best Practices, Techniques, And Resources â€” The first in a two-part series in which Hannah Milan covers best practices when using various 'text over image' techniques. Lots of visuals here to help make theÂ point.

Typograms: A Way to Render ASCII Diagrams More Elegantly â€” An intriguing project out of Google that lets you â€˜drawâ€™ diagrams in plain ASCII text within special script tags and these will then be rendered into nicer looking versions in the browser. An interesting approach if Mermaid is too full on for yourÂ needs.

Sam Goto / Google

svg-drawing: A Simple Canvas to Draw, "Replay", and Export SVG Line Art â€” You can deep link to any drawing, adjust some draw settings, and even change the options for playing back the drawing by animating theÂ lines. Please excuse my shoddy rocket drawing.

catsjuice

OGL 1.0: A Minimal WebGL Framework â€” WebGL is far from the easiest technology to use on its own, so libraries like Three.js are often used to make it more accessible. OGL has a similar motive while sticking closer to the WebGLÂ metal.

Nathan Gordon et al.

Mobile FIRST

MyTailwind: Interactively Customize Tailwind Components â€” Gives you a simple visual editor where you can customize styles for about 11 different components (button, navbar, card, sidebar, alert, etc.), then copy the HTML with the TailwindÂ classes.

noclip â€”Â A Digital Web-Based Museum of Video GameÂ Levels â€” This neat site is a browser-based way to explore levels from a variety of classic games. Iâ€™ve just been exploring the castle grounds of Super Mario 64 and the streets of GTA IIIâ€™s Liberty City. A cool nostalgia trip if nothing else. RepoÂ here. Three cheers forÂ WebGL!

#â€‹604 â€” August 2, 2023 | Read on the web

Generating Randomness in CSS with Trigonometry â€” A look at an interesting way to generate pseudo-random values in plain CSS by using some of the trigonometry functions it has to offer. Code and cool examplesÂ included. There's a lot more to this than first meets theÂ Ï€.

Kacper Kula

ğŸ‘ Support for these trig functions in CSS is surprisingly broad, too.

JavaScript Frontend Error Monitoring 101 â€” Take a crash (pun intended) course on frontend error monitoring with Sentry and learn how to identify and fix errors on a demo app. ReadÂ on.

Sentry sponsor

'If Web Components Are So Great, Why Am I Not Using Them?' â€” Do Web Components have a marketing problem? Dave thinks so, and shares what he thinks the issues are for this slowly-adoptedÂ technology.

Dave Rupert

CSS and Accessibility: Inclusion Through User Choice â€” Carie Fisher outlines which CSS media features are available for detecting user preferences and how they are used to design and build more inclusive userÂ experiences.

Smashing Magazine

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Rachel Andrew is back with another look over what was new to the web platform over the last month, including scroll-driven animations and the Privacy Sandbox APIs.

  • Here's the release notes for Safari Technology Preview 175.

  • Firefox 116's DevTools now support Custom Object formatters. This feature, supported by Chrome for years now, lets sites / libraries determine how certain types of object representation are formatted in the console andÂ debugger.

  • Vision for W3C: A new draft document outlining the "values, purpose, and principle" of the W3C's mission has been published.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

One-Time Permissions in Chrome â€” â€œAllow this timeâ€ is a new one-time option (from Chrome 16) for permission grants in Chrome. It will initially be available on desktop only for geolocation, camera, and microphoneÂ permissions.

Maud Nalpas (Chrome Developers)

Pausing and Resuming Animations in CSS â€” Did you know that you can pause and resume animations inÂ CSS? For example, pausing a distracting animation if you hover over an element,Â say.

Amit Merchant

â–¶Â Â 'Thatâ€™s Not How I Wrote CSS 3 Years Ago' â€” A trip down memory lane presenting some of the most significant impacts that changed how we approach CSS... and trying to predict future influences based on thatÂ past.

Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡

Build Better Software with DevCycleâ€™s Feature Flags â€” DevCycleâ€™s feature flag management platform helps you ship faster, release with confidence, and manage flags atÂ scale.

DevCycle sponsor

Ramona Schwering

The Virtual Keyboard API â€” Have you ever come across an issue where there is a fixed element on mobile, but it may end up hidden when the keyboard is activated? Ahmad explores the issue, why it happens, and how we can solve it with the virtual keyboardÂ API (in, admittedly, limited scenarios for now).

Ahmad Shadeed

Cassondra Roberts (Adobe / W3C)

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

a11y-dialog 8.0: A Lightweight, Accessible Way to Create Dialogs â€” Supports alert dialogs as per WAI-ARIA, nested dialogs, and provides both a DOM and JavaScript API. Thereâ€™s a live CodeSandbox demo you can playÂ with.

Kitty Giraudel

Random CSS Pattern Generator â€” Hit refresh and get a new, pure CSS background pattern each time â€” thereâ€™s a collection of more than 100 patternsÂ here, and you can customize the colors as you go.

Temani Afif

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Aniso: An Open Source ASCII Tool to Generate Text-BasedÂ Imagery â€” Allows you to upload various types of media files to automatically convert your media to an ASCII-based image. The results here areÂ cool.

Studio Freight

âœï¸ Web Font of the Week

Libre Caslon Condensed â€”Â A new open-source condensed serif "designed to fill the gap in the market for high-quality condensed serif alternatives". Ertekin shares ğŸ¦ more on this project on Twitter (or X, if youÂ will).

Parvus: Accessible Lightbox with No Dependencies â€” I love how it says not to use overlays on Web pages but if you have to, use this! Thereâ€™s a CodePenÂ example.

Benjamin de Oostfrees

ğŸ“±Â Praxis: An iOS Browser That Blocks JavaScript â€” Well, thatâ€™s certainly one way to fight back against prompts, modals, and battery sapping scripts, but it wonâ€™t work with everyÂ site..

Arnold Sakhnov

items.content:
frontend focus

#â€‹603 â€” July 26, 2023 | Read on the web

Core Web Vitals for Search Engine Optimization: What Do We Need to Know? â€” Harry aims to clear up any misunderstandings around core web vitals metrics and how they might impactÂ SEO. A well-sourcedÂ article.

Harry Roberts

Legibility: How and Why Typography Affects Ease of Reading â€” A free seven chapter book from a typographic expert covering letter spacing, alignment, layout, rendering, aesthetics, and much more. An excellent resource on typographic variables thatâ€™s well worth a read for getting up to speed on all things legibility, readability andÂ usability.

Mary C. Dyson

Get a Complete Picture of Your Siteâ€™s Performance â€” Track Core Web Vitals and learn how users experience the speed of your site. Use Lighthouse audits to fix issues. Measure the impact of slowdowns on business metrics and user engagement. Integrate with your CI/CD process to stayÂ fast.

SpeedCurve sponsor

The Arc Browser Reaches v1.0 â€” Iâ€™ve seen plenty of folks advocating for this new Chromium-powered browser â€”Â and now, following a period of being invite only, it's finally publicly downloadable as a 1.0 release. (Release notesÂ here)

The Browser Company

Google's 'Web Environment Integrity' Draft Draws Developer Ire â€” This is a developing story worth keeping an eye on. Google has proposed an idea called Web Environment Integrity (WEI) as a way for clients to establish their â€˜integrityâ€™ with a server by way of a third party. â€œIn simpler terms, WEI provides a way for a browser to prove it is working as a website operator expects, and hasnâ€™t been manipulated.â€ Unsurprisingly, many folks see where this couldÂ lead..

The Register

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • The folks at Devographics (the team behind the State of CSS) want your help in shaping the very first 'State of HTML' survey.

  • The third edition of the PNG spec has been published as a W3C WorkingÂ Draft.

  • The No CSS Club is, unsurprisingly, a collection of sites that use no CSS at all. Don't expect anything pretty, but they're certainlyÂ fast.

  • Cloudflare's Radar Domain Rankings now track global trendingÂ domains.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Idan Ram
